Mickey Shane

I was born to Mom, age 15, and Dad, age 16, many moons ago. I am an only child.
 
 This got me to wondering about being personally aborted. The stats seem to indicate that I would have been a good canidate. 
 
 I can only guess: My folks might have wanted to become parents at a later date. They would have produced an offspring. That child would have had a similar genetic make-up to mine. I suppose the child would have been either the brother, or the sister, that I never had. 
 
 Or, would it just be me, only younger?
 
 Would the undisputed King of the Cell Sacks have disliked being aborted?
 
 naw

I was born to Mom, age 15, and Dad, age 16, many moons ago. I am an only child.
 
 This got me to wondering about being personally aborted. The stats seem to indicate that I would have been a good canidate.

 or what if your parents just weren't in the mood to have sex that night? What if one of them had to work late? What if one was sick that night? What if they had gone on a trip to a different time zone and conceived you at a different time because they were asleep at the time you were conceived in real life. There are an endless list of possible reasons why you might not have been exactly you, and yes abortion is one of them. Of course here's one thing I know for sure. If she had the abortion, then you or whoever the next baby was, would be wondering what if she hadn't had the abortion :)

Ooaman

I know this is sort of a sub theme but the idea of asking the question "what if" is actually very profitable or not very profitable. Everytime a story is writen (either in book form or play/film form) the "What if" question has to be asked. Otherwise, you don't have a story to go with. The "what if" question that is asked can either me interesting or boring and you have to guess what the audience would think.
 There for, there is nothing wrong with asking "what if."
thelmoose

I know this is sort of a sub theme but the idea of asking the question "what if" is actually very profitable or not very profitable. The "what if" question that is asked can either me interesting or boring and you have to guess what the audience would think.
 There for, there is nothing wrong with asking "what if."

 
 I agree, but it depends upon what the "what if" question is. I think "what if I had been aborted" is essentially the same as "what if I had never been born", which is to me, an interesting existential question.
 
 I think given the question specifically mentions abortion and it is in an abortion thread, the original question has potentially a different implication. I don't see that it as any different than ask my equivalent question, but perhaps others do.

unkerpaulie

Not just the opposite gender version of yourself, but, like I used to wonder in fourth grade class, someone else?
 
 How did I happen to be me and not Ooaman, or Simone?
 
 Is this just what people would call my 'fate'?

 interesting. why call it 'fate' though? to me its just an empty label, and saying it was fate or it wasnt fate makes no difference. ervrybody that exists must have a "self" that is associated with that "body". its a one-to-one mapping, and neither would be here without the other. sometimes we entertain the idea of "selfs" and "bodies" exchanging (why am i me and not you?) but in any event the self that is associated with my body is me, even if it was you. if you were born in my body and i in yours, then i'd be you, which would be me, and you'd be me, which would be you. so it would make no difference if you think you're you or you think that the you that think's youre you is acyually somebody else. i very well maybe be you, but i like being you, because thats me, and i cant change that so ill continue being me, even if i'm being you
Mickey Shane
